factoid: The first act was over.
Everyone moved about in the stalls, going out and coming in.
Borís came to the Rostóvs' box.
Borís received the Rostóvs' congratulations very simply.
Borís raised his eyebrows with an absent‑mind smile.
Borís conveyed his fiancée's invitation to Natásha and Sónya.
Borís went away.
Natásha talked to Borís with a gay, coquettish smile.
Natásha congratulated Borís on his approaching wedding.
Natásha had formerly been in love with Borís.
Natásha was intoxicated.
Everything seemed simple and natural to Natásha.
The scantily clad Hélène smiled at everyone in the same way.
Natásha gave Borís a similar smile.
Hélène's box was filled.
Hélène's box was surrounded by distinguished and intellectual men from the stalls.
The distinguished and intellectual men vied with one another to show everyone that they knew Hélène.
During the entr'acte Karágin stood with Dólokhov in front of the orchestra partition.
Karágin looked at the Rostóvs' box.
Karágin was talking about Natásha.
Natásha knew that Karágin was talking about her.
Natásha felt pleasure.
Natásha turned so that Karágin could see her profile.
Natásha thought her profile was most becoming.
Pierre appeared in the stalls before the second act.
The Rostóvs had not seen Pierre since their arrival.
Pierre's face looked sad.
Pierre had grown stouter since Natásha last saw him.
Pierre passed up to the front rows.
Pierre did not notice anyone.
Anatole went up to Pierre and began speaking to him.
Anatole looked at and indicated the Rostóvs' box.
Pierre saw Natásha.
Pierre grew animated upon seeing Natásha.
Pierre hurried between the rows toward the Rostóvs' box.
Pierre leaned on his elbows and smiled.
Pierre talked to Natásha for a long time.
Natásha heard a man's voice in Countess Bezúkhova's box.
Natásha realized the voice was Karágin.
Natásha turned and her eyes met Karágin's.
Karágin almost smiled.
Karágin gazed straight into Natásha's eyes with an enraptured caressing look.
Natásha felt it was strange to be so near Karágin.
Natásha felt it was strange to look at Karágin like that.
Natásha felt it was strange to be sure that Karágin admired her.
Natásha felt it was strange to not be acquainted with Karágin.
The second act featured scenery representing tombstones.
The second act featured a round hole in the canvas to represent the moon.
In the second act shades were raised over the footlights.
Deep notes came from horns and contrabass in the second act.
Many people appeared from right and left wearing black cloaks and holding dagger‑like objects in the second act.
Those people began waving their arms.
Some people ran in and began dragging away the maiden who had been in white and was now in light blue.
They did not drag the maiden away immediately.
They sang with the maiden for a long time.
They eventually dragged the maiden off.
Something metallic was struck three times behind the scenes.
Everyone knelt down and sang a prayer.
The audience shouted enthusiastically repeatedly.
Every time Natásha looked toward the stalls, she saw Anatole Karágin with an arm thrown across the back of his chair staring at her.
Natásha was pleased to see that Anatole Karágin was captivated by her.
Natásha did not think there was anything wrong with it.
Countess Bezúkhova rose when the second act was over.
Countess Bezúkhova turned to the Rostóvs' box.
Countess Bezúkhova's whole bosom was completely exposed.
Countess Bezúkhova beckoned the old count with a gloved finger.
Countess Bezúkhova paid no attention to those who had entered her box.
Countess Bezúkhova began talking to the old count with an amiable smile.
Countess Bezúkhova said, 'Do make me acquainted with your charming daughters.'
Countess Bezúkhova said, 'The whole town is singing their praises and I don’t even know them!'
Natásha rose and curtsied to the splendid countess.
Natásha was pleased by praise from the splendid countess and blushed.
Hélène said, 'I want to become a Moscovite too, now.'
Hélène asked, 'How is it you’re not ashamed to bury such pearls in the country?'
Countess Bezúkhova had a reputation of being a fascinating woman.
Countess Bezúkhova could say what she did not think, especially what was flattering, quite simply and naturally.
